cdata.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 170, Number 80 (Wednesday, May 8, 2024)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. BARR:H.R. 8287.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article 1, Section 8 of the United States Constitution.The single subject of this legislation is:To require the Board of Governors of the Federal ReserveSystem to issue a rule relating to stress capital bufferrequirements.[Page H2998]

item.title: Bank Resilience and Regulatory Improvement Act

latestAction.text: Placed on the Union Calendar, Calendar No. 651.

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services.

bill.title: Stress Testing Accountability and Transparency Act

item.title: Stress Testing Accountability and Transparency Act
Stress Testing Accountability and Transparency Act
To require the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System to issue a rule relating to stress capital buffer requirements, and for other purposes.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
